title: Visa on Arrival Overview
content: Indonesia offers Visa on Arrival (VoA) for eligible nationalities, valid for 30 days and extendable once for another 30 days.

title: Electronic Visa on Arrival
content: Travelers can apply for an e-VoA online before arriving, allowing faster processing at the airport.

title: Passport Validity Rule
content: Your passport must be valid for at least six months from your date of entry into Indonesia.

title: Return Ticket Requirement
content: Immigration may require proof of onward or return travel when entering the country.

title: Tourist Stay Extensions
content: Tourist visas can typically be extended once at a local immigration office, requiring biometric data.

title: Overstay Penalties
content: Overstaying incurs daily fines and potential detention for long overstays; avoid exceeding your allowed duration.

title: Visa-Free Entry Rules
content: Indonesia suspended many visa-free policies; check current eligibility before travel.

title: Work Restrictions on Tourist Visas
content: Employment or volunteer work is strictly prohibited on tourist visas, with penalties for violations.

title: Business Visa Basics
content: A business visa allows attending meetings but not employment; duration varies by sponsor.

title: Customs Declaration Process
content: Arrivals must complete a customs declaration, available digitally, covering goods, cash, and food items.

title: Cash Limit Regulations
content: Amounts over 100 million IDR (or equivalent) must be declared upon entry.

title: Restricted Items
content: Drugs, weapons, and certain pharmaceuticals require permits and are heavily regulated.

title: COVID-era Requirements
content: Health regulations change frequently; insurance or vaccination proof may be required depending on updates.

title: Ride-Hailing Apps
content: Gojek and Grab are the most commonly used ride-hailing services for cars and motorbikes.

title: Motorbike Taxis
content: Motorbike taxis, called 'ojek', are fast and economical, ideal for busy city traffic.

title: TransJakarta Bus System
content: Jakarta has a dedicated-lane bus system called TransJakarta, offering cheap citywide travel.

title: Jakarta MRT
content: The MRT runs north–south through central Jakarta, providing efficient and clean transit.

title: Intercity Trains
content: Java Island has reliable trains connecting Jakarta, Bandung, Yogyakarta, and Surabaya.

title: Ferry Travel
content: Ferries connect major islands; popular routes include Bali–Nusa Penida and Java–Bali.

title: Driving Restrictions
content: Driving requires an international driving permit; road conditions vary widely across regions.

title: Traffic Congestion
content: Large cities often experience heavy traffic, especially during rush hours and holidays.

title: Long-Distance Buses
content: Intercity buses serve distant provinces, with VIP classes offering recliners and AC.

title: Rail Ticket Booking
content: Train tickets can be purchased online through the official KAI app or website.

title: Scooter Rentals
content: Renting scooters is popular in tourist areas but requires caution and proper licensing.

title: Taxis
content: Blue Bird is a trusted taxi company known for using meters reliably.

title: Airport Transfers
content: Airports offer fixed-rate taxis and online booking options for reliable transfers.

title: Bali Overview
content: Bali is Indonesia’s most famous island, known for beaches, temples, and cultural experiences.

title: Ubud Cultural Hub
content: Ubud offers traditional crafts, rice terraces, and spiritual retreats.

title: Nusa Penida Highlights
content: Nusa Penida features dramatic cliffs, Kelingking Beach, and crystal-clear snorkeling spots.

title: Jakarta Old Town
content: Kota Tua contains colonial-era buildings, museums, and vibrant street life.

title: Borobudur Temple
content: Borobudur in Central Java is the world’s largest Buddhist temple, famed for its sunrise views.

title: Prambanan Temple
content: Prambanan is a 9th-century Hindu temple complex known for its tall spires and evening ballet shows.

title: Mount Bromo
content: Mount Bromo is an active volcano with stunning sunrise viewpoints in East Java.

title: Komodo National Park
content: Komodo National Park is home to Komodo dragons and world-class diving sites.

title: Lake Toba
content: Lake Toba in North Sumatra is a volcanic lake featuring Batak culture and scenic landscapes.

title: Raja Ampat
content: Raja Ampat offers some of the richest marine biodiversity and pristine diving in the world.

title: Gili Islands
content: The Gili Islands are car-free tropical islands popular for diving and relaxed beaches.

title: Yogyakarta City
content: Yogyakarta is a cultural center known for arts, history, and access to Borobudur and Prambanan.

title: Bandung Highlands
content: Bandung offers cool weather, art scenes, and tea plantations in the surrounding highlands.

title: Tana Toraja
content: Tana Toraja is known for unique funeral traditions and dramatic traditional houses.

title: Bunaken Marine Park
content: Bunaken in North Sulawesi is renowned for exceptional wall diving.

title: Belitung Island
content: Belitung is famous for white granite boulders, calm beaches, and island hopping.

title: Lombok Beaches
content: Lombok offers quieter alternatives to Bali with surf spots and scenic coastline.

title: Mount Rinjani
content: Mount Rinjani is a challenging trek with crater lake views on Lombok.

title: Seminyak
content: Seminyak is a trendy area with upscale dining, boutiques, and sunset bars.

title: Canggu
content: Canggu is popular with surfers and digital nomads, offering cafes and beach clubs.

title: Kuta Beach
content: Kuta is Bali’s most famous surf and nightlife district, suitable for beginners.

title: Nusa Dua
content: Nusa Dua features luxury resorts and calm beaches ideal for families.

title: Sanur
content: Sanur is known for a quiet seaside promenade and gentle waters.

title: Uluwatu Temple
content: Uluwatu Temple sits on a cliff edge and is famous for Kecak dance performances.

title: Tanah Lot Temple
content: Tanah Lot is an iconic sea temple best visited during sunset.

title: Menjangan Island
content: Menjangan in West Bali is known for calm, clear waters ideal for snorkeling.

title: Malang
content: Malang offers colonial architecture and access to Bromo and Tumpak Sewu waterfall.

title: Tumpak Sewu Waterfall
content: Tumpak Sewu is a dramatic multi-tiered waterfall often called the Niagara of Indonesia.

title: Karimunjawa Islands
content: Karimunjawa is a remote archipelago with pristine beaches and coral reefs.

title: Aceh's Baiturrahman Mosque
content: Aceh’s grand mosque is an architectural landmark with deep historical significance.

title: Medan Food Scene
content: Medan is known for rich culinary diversity, including Batak, Malay, and Indian influences.

title: Makassar Fort Rotterdam
content: Fort Rotterdam is a Dutch-era fort showcasing regional history.

title: Papua Baliem Valley
content: Baliem Valley offers trekking and encounters with highland Papuan cultures.

title: Derawan Islands
content: Derawan Islands are known for manta rays, jellyfish lakes, and turquoise waters.

title: Ancol Dreamland
content: Ancol in Jakarta is a seaside recreation area with theme parks and beaches.

title: Monas Tower
content: Monas is Jakarta’s national monument and offers panoramic city views.

title: Surabaya Old Town
content: Surabaya’s historical quarter includes colonial buildings and heritage cafés.

title: Banyuwangi Ijen Crater
content: Ijen Crater is famous for blue flames and sulfur mining.

title: Flores Kelimutu Lakes
content: Kelimutu features three volcanic lakes that change colors due to mineral reactions.

title: Wakatobi National Park
content: Wakatobi is a marine paradise known for coral diversity and sustainable tourism.

title: Bogor Botanical Gardens
content: Bogor Botanical Gardens contain thousands of tropical plant species.

title: Garut Hot Springs
content: Garut offers natural hot spring resorts in a mountain setting.

title: Belitung Museum
content: The Belitung Museum highlights tin-mine history and local culture.

title: Padang Beachfront
content: Padang is known for beaches and as a gateway to the Mentawai Islands.

title: Mentawai Surfing
content: The Mentawai Islands offer world-class surf breaks.

title: Bromo Tengger National Park
content: This national park includes vast volcanic landscapes and the Tengger caldera.

title: Labuan Bajo
content: Labuan Bajo is the gateway to Komodo National Park with growing tourism facilities.

title: Jakarta Chinatown (Glodok)
content: Glodok is one of the oldest Chinatowns, offering temples and street food.

title: Bali Rice Terraces
content: Tegalalang and Jatiluwih terraces display Bali’s traditional subak irrigation.

title: Sumba Traditional Villages
content: Sumba offers unique megalithic tombs and grass-roof houses.

title: Banda Islands
content: The Banda Islands are historic nutmeg islands with pristine reefs.

title: Jakarta Grand Indonesia Mall
content: Grand Indonesia is a major shopping complex with diverse dining.

title: Safari Park Indonesia
content: Bogor’s Taman Safari offers drive-through wildlife experiences.

title: Bali Waterfalls
content: Sekumpul and Gitgit waterfalls offer scenic trekking and cool pools.

title: Manado Highlands
content: The Manado highlands offer cool climates and volcano treks like Mount Lokon.

title: Traffic Awareness
content: Urban traffic is chaotic; always check both directions when crossing streets.

title: Motorbike Safety
content: Wear helmets and avoid riding in heavy rain due to slippery roads.

title: Food Safety
content: Eat at busy stalls and restaurants to ensure food freshness.

title: Drink Water Caution
content: Tap water is not potable; always use bottled or filtered water.

title: Pickpocketing Risks
content: Be vigilant in crowded areas like markets and bus terminals.

title: ATM Safety
content: Use ATMs located in malls or banks to reduce the risk of skimming.

title: Natural Hazards
content: Some regions are prone to earthquakes or volcanic activity; follow local advisories.

title: Beach Safety
content: Rip currents exist in many beaches; swim only in designated safe areas.

title: Wildlife Safety
content: Do not feed monkeys in tourist areas; they may become aggressive.

title: Scam Awareness
content: Be cautious about overpriced tours; compare prices before booking.

title: Night Safety
content: Stick to well-lit areas and use registered transport at night.

title: Weather Precautions
content: Rainy season can cause flooding; plan extra travel time.

title: Health Precautions
content: Mosquito protection is recommended to avoid dengue risk.

title: Greetings
content: A polite greeting often includes a slight nod or handshake using the right hand.

title: Right-Hand Rule
content: Always use your right hand when giving or receiving objects.

title: Modest Clothing
content: Dress modestly in rural areas and religious sites.

title: Temple Etiquette
content: Remove shoes before entering temples and dress respectfully.

title: Public Affection
content: Public displays of affection are generally frowned upon.

title: Pointing Etiquette
content: Avoid pointing with your index finger; gesture with your whole hand instead.

title: Hospitality Norms
content: Guests are often offered drinks; politely accept or decline.

title: Entering Homes
content: Remove your shoes when entering someone’s home.

title: Respect for Elders
content: Elders are addressed politely and given deference in conversation.

title: Photography Etiquette
content: Ask permission before photographing people, especially in villages.

title: Quiet Voices
content: Speaking loudly in public is considered rude.

title: Feet Etiquette
content: Avoid pointing your feet at people or religious objects.

title: Gift-Giving
content: Gifts are usually given with the right hand and not opened immediately.

title: Drug Laws
content: Indonesia enforces strict drug laws with severe penalties.

title: Smoking Areas
content: Smoking is restricted in many public areas; look for designated zones.

title: Alcohol Regulations
content: Alcohol availability varies; some regions restrict or ban alcohol.

title: Drone Regulations
content: Drone use requires respecting no-fly zones, including airports and government buildings.

title: Public Conduct
content: Public intoxication or disruptive behavior can lead to fines or arrest.

title: Environmental Rules
content: Many areas enforce bans on single-use plastics.

title: Protected Wildlife
content: Buying or trading protected animal products is illegal.

title: Cultural Heritage Protection
content: Damaging temples or heritage sites can result in heavy penalties.

title: Visa Status Checks
content: Tourists must carry ID or digital copies and may be asked to show visa status.

title: Internet Restrictions
content: Some regions may experience temporary internet blocks during major events.

title: Currency Regulations
content: Payments are legally required in Indonesian Rupiah, even in tourist areas.

title: Photography Restrictions
content: Photography is prohibited in some government and military areas.

title: Littering Laws
content: Littering fines apply in many cities and tourist destinations.
